ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How various traditions view "the good life," both religious and non-religious
I gained a lot of valuable tools for thinking about what makes a life worth living, and for developing my own vision of that life.
using different religious practices or philosophies about life as lenses to see the world
I was able to analyze and synthesize across religious, philosophical, and social traditions in order to build a stronger understanding of my vision of life worth living.
How to analyze traditions and religions, and how to think about how they fit together (and complement each other) in our lives.

Throughout this class, we read texts relating to different ideologies/schools of thought/religions about what makes life worth living. We wrestled with questions relating to what it means to lead life well, experience life feeling good, or have life go well. Every week, we all read the same texts and followed various discussion questions in small and large groups.
I learned alot about different traditions and their perspective on how to make a life worth living and what that even means.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this is a great class with a robust syllabus and wonderful teachers; there are a lot of differences (in discussions, grading, etc) among sections, so choose carefully. my particular section was very philosophical which I didn't love, but it has a great list of texts that allow for good discussion. Some readings seemed unnecessary and got to be very long
This is a great class. Obviously it was sad to have to take it over zoom, but the professors really made an effort to make us feel present in the class. The virtual retreat was great.
incredible class culture. Everyone really cared about each other
This is an absolutely amazing course! Not much to really improve  even the breakout rooms were fantastic and well thought out (which is rare for a virtual class).

The course has a very broad range of different ideas of what makes life worth living. It was facilitated well to address concerns, doubts, and other points of interest. Honestly, the only weakness of the course is that we didnt have time to do more of each topic or do more comparative work (even though that happened naturally).

Strength: so many. Reallly makes you think and also your classmates make up much of the environment

Weakness: Heavily dependant on the TA. Ryan is the best TA for discussion but is a very harsh grader. You will lose points on participation for being a few minutes late to class. Other TAs hand easy As but discussion might not be the best.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: zoom seminars (including breakout rooms) were super successful, actually, and allowed for really good discussions

This is the kind of class that really does work best in person. It's all about community. That said, things like the virtual retreat worked well. Having fun daily "check-in" questions was also a really important strategy that helped the class bond.

The virtual blackboard worked fantastically as a means of communication and recordkeeping across class sessions. Having something tangible to work with across small and large group discussions was very helpful as a teaching tool.
See above.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would! I generally really enjoyed this course. There is a lot of variance between sections, which can be a little annoying/frustrating. It was a bit more work than I expected, but I truly enjoyed most of the work. It was a great class to take second semester senior year. It didn't change my life but forced me to think about a lot of important questions.

This is a great class! Really fun and community-oriented. It works best if you don't think of it as a world religions survey. The point isn't to learn about different world religions, but rather to use them as jumping-off points to consider your own values and assumptions and (hopefully) come to some real conclusions you can take with you after you leave Yale.
yes. incredible, life changing experience

Yes. Especially HUMS 411 with Ryan McNally Linz. He is the type of professor who thinks about teaching in earnest, as can be seen through his relentless dedication to cultivating fruitful class discussion. Reading a variety of materials across traditions is something I wouldn't have done myself, and it was even better that I had a wonderful class and professor with which to discuss those materials with.
Absolutely! If you can take this course, especially with Ryan, you should! Itll make you think about your life, and especially your time at Yale and after, in a different way.

I would recommend this class to every single Yale student. The class provides a space for deep discussion about the things each student values about life, or thinks is true about life, which is a rare opportunity at Yale. It was great to be able to raise doubts and ask hard questions and to really think critically about life and what makes it worth living as a class.
I would definitely recommend it, but I would say to take it Credit/D if you want to take it with Ryan, who is the best TA. This is not a gut if you take it with him.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual seminar; prerecorded asynchronous lectures about every other week
We had a virtual seminar with recorded lectures.
